segment.tokens: A very observant naturalist says "
soon as any one appears in the fields where the nest is
where the nest is
As the bird runs quietly rapidly in a stooping posture to some distance from it
the bird then rises with loud cries and appearance of alarm
as if her nest was immediately below the spot
she rose from
When the young ones are hatched
too the place to look for them is _ not
where the parent birds are screaming fluttering about at some little distance from it
As soon as you actually come to the spot where their young are
where their young are
the old birds alight on the ground a hundred yards so from you
watching your movements
If however you pick up one of the young ones
both male female immediately throw off all disguise about to fly in your face "
both male female come wheeling screaming around your head about to fly in your face
Peewits are certainly bold
when their young ones are in danger
Mr. Charles St. John says
he has often seen
the hooded crows hunting the fields
frequented the peewits as regularly as a pointer
the hooded crows flying a few yards above the ground
the hooded crows searching for the eggs
The cunning crow always selects the time
when the old birds are away on the shore
as he is perceived
As soon however the peewits all combine chasing him away
We are told
that they will also attack any bird prey that ventures near their breeding ground
they are too
the cock birds will fight with each other
should
they come into too close quarters
A cock bird one day attacked a wounded male bird
a wounded male bird came near his nest
the pugnacious little fellow ran up to the intruder
taking advantage of his weakness , jumped on him ,
jumped on him
pecking at his head
the pugnacious little fellow dragged him along the ground as fiercely as a game cock
This was witnessed Mr. St. John
I have often heard peewits uttering their peculiar noise
[ A ] " " said Willy " quite late at night
What do they feed
I should so much like to have a tame young one "
The food of the peewits consists of insects , worms , snails , slugs , the larvæ of various insects
I am they much good to the farmer destroying numerous insect-pests
do
" exclaimed May "
" Oh papa do come here "
what a splendid cluster of bright golden flowers is growing on the side of the drain
Yes indeed it is a beautiful
it is the
it looks like a gigantic buttercup
it is sometimes in flower as early as March
it continues to blossom for three months or more
Country people often call it the may-flower
once used for may-garlands
I dare say
you have sometimes seen wreaths
hanging on cottage doors
Some people have invented
what I think very ugly names for this showy plant , such as horse-blob , water-blob
" Beneath the shelving bank 's retreat The horseblob swells its golden ball "
I have somewhere read
that the young buds are sometimes pickled
the young buds used of capers
I do not think
I should like to try them
" asked May
" And what " are those bright green feathery under the water
they are very pretty "
they do not bear any flowers
No there are no flowers at present
in about a month 's time you will see plenty
of the middle of the feathery tuft there grows a single tall stem with whorls of four , five , or six pale purple flowers occurring at intervals
occurring at intervals
Its English name is not a fitting name for it
because this plant is not at all related to the violet tribe
is one of the primrose family
so we should more correctly call it water-primrose
it is called Hottonia in honour of a German botanist , Professor Hotton , of Leyden
Willy will tell us
that the word _ palustris _ means " marshy " in allusion to the places where the water primrose is found growing
where the water primrose is found
growing
It is a very common in the ditches on the moors here
I will take care to show you its pretty tall stem
its pretty tall stem when the flowers appear
While I was talking to May about the water primrose
Jack espied a sulphur-coloured butterfly
off he set in full chase
he did not however succeed capturing it
for his foot tripped over a molehill
down he tumbled
the beautiful sulphur butterfly having fled across a wide ditch
he escaped
where he fell
there was a thorn bush a number of unfortunate moles
some had been killed quite recently so
I took three four from the thorn with the intention of taking them home and examining their stomachs to see what they had eaten
what they had eaten
In the meantime down we sat on an adjoining bank covered with primroses looking so gay and smelling so sweet
covered primroses looking so gay smelling so sweet
Willy then wanted to know the history of the mole
why people generally think it right to kill these animals
whether they really are
May of course could not resist the charm collecting primroses for mamma
The two boys cared more for animals so
I answered their questions about the mole
I pointed out the amazing strength of its feet , its soft and silky fur
First of all I pointed out the amazing strength of its feet , its soft and silky fur the form of its body so well adapted for a rapid progress through the underground passages it forms
it forms
Look I said at its soft fur
how it will lie in any direction
each delicate hair is inserted in the skin perpendicularly to its surface
so that the mole can move rapidly either backwards forwards with great ease
lying as readily in one direction as another
the fur makes no difficulty to a backward retreat
If you look closely
when I push away the fur with my finger and breath in the neighbourhood of the eyes
you will see two tiny black specs
so we can hardly call the mole a blind animal
as it lives for the most part
underground its power of vision must be
The fore feet do the work of the spade and potato-fork combined
its sense of smell is
this no doubt aids the animal in the search of its food
the mole sense of hearing is also very
" Well but papa " exclaimed Jack
" a mole has got no ears so
how can it hear "
There is no outward appearance of ears
it is
no outward appearance of ears look
I blow away the fur
now you see clearly a hole
a hole is the of the passage that leads to the internal ear
the passage leads to the internal ear
The ears of many animals are very admirably made
The ears of many animals fitted for the purpose of receiving sounds
you must not suppose
because some animals as moles , seals , whales , & c. have no outward appendages
that they are of ears and the power of hearing
you must wait
till you are a little
then I will explain to you the matter more fully
The little curiously shaped earbones are found in all mammalia
The little curiously shaped earbones are found also in the mole
